subtitle: Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. I imagine that by now many of you
already realized that, in conjunction with White
Crow Books, we've just launched the new Thinking
Allowed Dialogues book imprint. Our first title is, Is There Life After Death?
Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge
and discovery, with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Our
topic today is The Making of a Paranormal
Investigator. With me today here in Albuquerque
is Robert Bigelow. Robert is the founder of the
Bigelow Institute for Consciousness Studies. He
also founded the National Institute for Discovery
Science. He was the recipient of millions of
dollars in federal government money for a research
program called the Advanced Aerospace Weapons
System Application Program. Robert is responsible
for millions of dollars in grants and gifts to
people working in the paranormal community. I
myself am the recipient of the Bigelow Institute's
grant, not a grant, contest for the best essay
about evidence for survival after death. When I
received that award, I acknowledged Robert for
doing more probably than any other person to
awaken people to the evidence for life after
death and for stimulating the research community.
So, it's an honor for me to be with you today,
Robert. Thank you for coming to Albuquerque.
Thank you, Jeffrey. You know, and I kind of look
at you as the godfather of the entire field, you
know, of consciousness studies. So, you're a bit
intimidating sitting here and my humble little
self here and being interviewed by such a famous
person as yourself. Well, I can sort of feel the
same way. You are an intimidating figure in your
own right, I think for many people, Robert. But
what we're going to do now is talk about your
early years, how you became the person who you now
are. I'm grateful and I want to let our viewers
know that we're going to be conducting several
interviews while you're here in Albuquerque. This
is the first one. We'll be talking quite a bit
about your investigations. I didn't even mention
in the introduction the Bigelow Aerospace
Corporation, your interest in space exploration
and your interest in the paranormal and how they
come together. But let's start out with your humble
childhood, growing up in Las Vegas at a time when
the city, which is now over three million people,
had just a few thousand. Yeah, when I was born
there and, you know, at that time there might have
been 20-some thousand, maybe 25,000. I was blessed
to be growing up in that environment. There were
so many things that were so interesting in the 40s
and in the 50s. You know, that's back when so many
of the atomic bombs were going off above ground.
So all of us that are still around that lived there
at that time have seen a lot of mushroom clouds
and we were let out in the schoolyard to go see
them if they were afternoon shots. You know, a lot
of the shots were at night or early morning so that
the winds were mild or non-existent at that time.
Those crackers were phenomenal to watch. Usually
the kilotons was between maybe 10 or 12 kilotons
to 150 max in that kind of range. And there were
over 700 shots above and below ground. So we were
used to the tremors and to the quakes of them and
it was a lot of fun. And a lot of the houses that
had plaster ceilings always had a crack running
down their living room, you know, because the
plaster would eventually crack with the constant
shaking like that. Of course, Nellis Air Force
Base was there and that was a very active air base.
And back in that time, they would break the sound
barrier. And at that time, the protocols for
not doing that just weren't either enforced that
stringently or they didn't exist. So you'd hear
this ka-bam, boom, you know, and I'd be out
digging a foxhole or something in my backyard,
which I built a lot of, I built a two-story tree
house, you know, and a lot of foxholes and things.
And so, it was a great time to grow up. You
could take your BB gun and go shooting anywhere.
I lived about two miles from downtown Las Vegas, which was out in the country.
That was out in the, you know, out in the
country. There were other houses around, but
in 10 minutes in a car, you could be out where
nobody was, you know. Now, it takes you an hour
to get across the valley if you're lucky, you know,
if it's not work time. So, it was a fascinating
place to grow up. And night and day difference,
today's environment has no, none of the characteristics
of what would excite a kid. Coming along with that
came stories of my friends of mine seeing UFOs,
or their parents, and those were not uncommon.
And I don't think it was coincidence.
There were exploding these huge bombs, and ET
UFOs would have an interest in that, you know,
of course. It was a fun time for a kid. It was really great.
Yeah. And as I recall, you were able to drive
at a very young age, and even owned a car at a
young age.
I did. And I got away with a superb con job on
my parents. I had friends that had motorcycles,
motor scooters, and motorcycles. And they were always having a broken hand, or leg,
or something like that, right? Or arm. And I said,
you know, look dad, I don't want a motorcycle,
because I want something around me. I want something heavy around me. And we had been,
he had a World War II Jeep. And since I was a kid, I got used to driving the standard,
the three-speed shift on the Jeep. And even
when I was about 11, I was alone in the seat,
he would be next to me. But I wasn't sitting on
his lap or anything. I would be alone driving
that Jeep, you know. And so, when I was 13, I
convinced him. And I think, you know, it was
logical that, well, the kid doesn't want to ride
a bicycle anymore, you know. And his friends all
can go tens of miles, which was huge, you know,
or 50 miles in one day, easily on a motorcycle.
So, that was a big deal when you're graduating
from a bicycle. So, he let me buy a car and I
wanted something different. I wanted, you know,
I've always been a little different, weird in
some kind of ways, you know, a maverick in some kind of ways. So, I wanted a Model A.
So, I spent every dime I had, $175, I'd saved
up. And I had my first job was during the summer,
when I was 13. So, some of the money came
from that job. It was in an ice cream store,
like a Dairy Queen, only it wasn't a brand, it was a mom and pop kind of thing. And so,
I made hamburgers and stuff like that, you know, hot dogs was the part of the menu.
And I loved that car, absolutely loved it. And he
got enthused with it too, because for Christmas,
he gave me a brand new Candy Apple paint job on
the Model A. And it had a rumble seat in the back
and four cylinder. And he also gave me a new leather upholstery job for the car.
So, that was a dream to me. That was fantastic.
And you're 13 years old.
I'm 13 years old. By the time I was 14, I was driving all over, all over the place,
all over town, all around the neighborhoods
to my friends, you know, and thinking kind of
nothing of it, you know, I thought, you know, I
didn't get in any accidents or anything like that,
because I knew how to handle the car, you know. Later, we put a V8 in it.
Oh, my.
Yeah, yeah. We put a V8 in it, like a 48 Merc
or something like that, you know, that had,
I think we milled the heads and we may have
bored and stroked it. And we put on a couple of,
I think, two or three deuces carburetors on there, you know.
You made it into a hot rod.
You know, and I think my father was living through
me at the time, because he grew up really poor,
where they actually would have a meal. He and
his sisters would sit down and they would have
a meal that would be, you know, you count how
many peas and how many carrot pieces you have
on your plate, you know. And so, he never had
anything like that. We didn't dream of it,
you know. And his father was a prospector, always
out and an inventor. His father, Leroy Bigelow,
was an inventor in different kinds of things
that would process gold to be able to,
either through different kinds of means of
processing finds and winding up with the dust or
the, you know, nuggets or whatever. Most of the
time, he didn't find anything, but he was always
looking. And so, most of the time, there wasn't
any money, you know, to support the family.
So, my dad was really enthused and with me,
because I was the only kid. I didn't have any
siblings, no brothers or sisters. And so, I was blessed because we always played a lot
of sports together and did things together out
in the desert, looking for pottery or arrowheads
or caves or anything, a rattlesnake, whatever,
you know. So, any interesting rocks or whatever.
So, I was blessed.
So, it was a happy childhood.
Oh, yeah. It was hard to explain how neat it was. Yeah.
At the same time, there were UFO activities. It
was very rare, I suppose, that the people in Las
Vegas saw all of these nuclear explosions. I
grew up in Wisconsin. Of course, I've never seen
an atomic explosion. But your parents or your
grandparents, I should say, your grandparents
who lived nearby had a UFO encounter when you were a very young child.
Yeah. We lived right next door, immediately
adjacent to my mother and father, my maternal
grandparents. And he had given his two daughters
each an acre right next to them. So, my dad and
mother built a house on the acre that he gave
my mother. And it was a blessing to have my
grandparents there because they were neat people.
So, in 1947, I had just turned three years old.
And it was in about early June of that year,
they had a really close, super close encounter.
There was nothing to do in Las Vegas except go
for ice cream cones, you know, or take drives
someplace on, you know, if you're not working during the week, you know, so.
So, they had left in a later afternoon and
they went up a remote road going up to Mount
Charleston, up to Kyle Canyon. And they were
coming back down and they saw this light,
then it was kind of glowing. And they thought
maybe it was a plane and maybe then it kept
glowing more and getting larger and thought,
well, maybe it's on fire. And it was coming
toward them. And it got to where it began to
be obvious it was really coming toward them.
And they pulled off to the side of the road.
And just as they stopped the car, the object
filled the entire windshield up. And then at
the split last second, they could see as they're
trying to duck, they could see this thing just take off, you know, lightning quick.
And I never knew this story until I was about 10
or 11 years old. I didn't know it. I was three at
the time it happened. I didn't know the story
until I was 10 or 11. And so, I did remember that
my mom told me the story and she said they were
late getting back into town. And I said, well,
why? And she said, well, it must have taken
your grandfather some time to get his composure.
You know, after that kind of experience. But that's kind of relevant because,
you know, if you do abduction research and so forth, missing time is important.
Part of the calculus of determining did an event happen and all that. So,
then I went to my grandfather and asked him about
the story. And he wouldn't talk about it. He
wouldn't talk to me, which wasn't like him, but he wouldn't talk about it.
And then I went to my grandmother and she barely talked about it. She just mentioned
just a little bit, not much of anything.
Like it was just taboo or they were scared to
talk about it or something. And I think, you
know, the psychology of that must have been
so impactful of that event happening. And I kind
of maybe just kind of chalked it up to that.
So, that was one time that that happened. And
then later, my mother was with them during daytime
and they saw a craft over what was called
Sheep Mountain. And they were in that vicinity.
And it was large. And then it just disappeared.
It didn't move. It was just gone type of thing.
So, back in those years, those are my two family experiences,
aside from friends of mine who said, oh, you know, I'm not supposed to tell you.
My dad's going to kill me, but here's what
happened, you know, on our way back from hunting.
You know, at night we came back through Alamo and
here's what we saw that landed alongside the road.
And I was begging my dad and the other fellow,
don't get out of the car. We had no truck. We
were riding in the truck back from our hunting
trip. And so, stories like that stick with you.
So, you had those stories around you, people
around you, but you also, as you explained to me,
had a series of, we could call them recurring
dreams, but there might have been more than
dreams. They could have been. I just, you know, I
don't have any evidence that there were anything
other than dreams. It was just, they were peculiar because it was the same damn dream
about five or six times over the course of months. So, I'd be in my little bedroom,
my twin bed, laying down sideways and I'm looking
at three figures in monk type of robes or hoods.
I couldn't see faces, appendages, anything. And there's three of them there facing me
and I'm thinking, what do you want and why are you here?
There was no other kind of communication at all.
And I'm not even doing this out loud in my dream.
I'm just thinking this, right? And the dream
is over. Well, what a stupid dream to have.
Can't it be something nice where you're having
the biggest, you know, banana split in history?
That would be a good dream, right? So, I just
chalked it up to crazy kind of dreams, but there
was nothing in the media. We didn't get
television until I was about 10 or 11 years old.
And I had these dreams when I was six or seven or
eight, somewhere in that seven or eight time frame.
And did it for comic books, which I was an
avid reader of comic books, but there were no
characters that were drawn like that. You know,
there weren't any. And at least that I ever had,
that I ever read, didn't know about them. So,
what it suggests to me is that very likely
your grandparents had more of an encounter than
they remember, and that it's possible that some
entities from another realm were watching you ever since childhood.
It's remotely possible. And we have, you know, as researchers, we discover
historically that that kind of lineage, that
kind of those experiences occur in generational
families where you may have grandparents and then parents and then children.
It's kind of flows together like that, but I don't know. I just chalk it up to...
We don't have to make anything of it, but there came a time in your life prior to the
inauguration of your formal research projects, then the development of NIDS,
where you began a serious investigation of
UFO and UFO contactees. And to my knowledge,
this is something that the world doesn't know about you.
Well, at the time when I was 10 to 12 year old
timeframe in there, my father began to read
about UFOs and he would read books that were authored by military people,
credible ones. And I think he and my grandfather probably had a conversation
about my grandfather's experience. And so, I think
that's where he got that from. And he and I would
talk about it when I was, you know, 11, 12 years old. And I would say,
Dad, so Dad, would you... If one landed there,
one landed out in the field behind our house,
what would you do? Would you go up to it?
He said, yeah, I would. Now, my dad wasn't a
bullshitter. He was a paratrooper in World War
II. And he had bronze stars, two bronze stars,
and purple hearts, and he'd been through a lot.
And so, he was no-nonsense kind of guy. And he
just wouldn't lead me on like that. And I
believed him. I believed that he would do that,
you know. And I got inspired by it, I think,
at an early age and thought, wow, you know,
if it's true, it's really holy cow. Wow, really
amazing. And I started reading a little bit of
the books he had. And I don't know if it
was Major Kehoe or Jesse Marcel or somebody,
I forget the authors now. But they were credible
authors. And they had no real reason to make
things up like that. Because it would hurt
their careers. And they were at risk and hurting
themselves. You know, when I was 10 years old,
in the mid-50s, I was also reading all the UFO
books I could find in the library. And I remember
as a 10-year-old child, I wrote a letter to
Donald Menzel at Harvard University. And he wrote back to me to assure me that there
was nothing to any of this. Well, so much for experts, right?
So, I guess UFOs were in the air. And it's
wonderful you could discuss it with your father.
I was always kind of an explorer kid, you know.
And he was, as an adult, interested in anything
that was over the hill. What's on the other side?
You know, let's go check this out or whatever.
And so, I was just used to that way of thinking.
You know, why have a closed mind about anything?
Why not look at all the evidence you can? And I
have faith, but I have more faith in evidence,
right? And I want to believe certain things like everybody does. You know,
you want to believe certain things. But I
believe there's a God force, a supreme force,
not based on faith of Scripture or what I'm
told. And my mother was a very religious woman,
and so was my grandmother. But I have more faith if I can have evidence that I can see
as tangible and really as logical. And it's
huge, it's abundant, right? I love that. Okay,
now take it and go somewhere with it. Yeah. And actually, consciousness research and
even an area as ephemeral as life after death, there are mountains of evidence.
Yes, absolutely huge, huge. Well, I gather at the same time,
in your childhood, you were also being inspired by the space program.
Yeah, well, Sputnik was a Sputnik, whatever. It
was 57, right? And the worry was the Russians had
more throw capacity than we did. And so, that
was like, oh my gosh, we can have an ICBM
land in our country with a nuclear bomb. And
so, boy, the landing on the moon was amazing,
to watch that and Walter Cronkite get all teary-eyed like everybody did at that time,
because it was such an emotional achievement. And
it was for the human race. Yeah, Americans did it.
Americans, that was a time, Americans really
had the right stuff, not only to really help win
World War II, but to also get into something
that's not political, like space, and actually
demonstrate that kind of an achievement. And have
those images of those guys walking on the moon,
it was just really amazing to see it in real time.
I presume that maybe the inspiration that led you to build an aerospace company
began around then.
Yeah, I had a little workshop in a little part of
the attic, where I was playing around with things
to kind of, you know, a little electronic kind of stuff, make-believe kind of things,
and maybe some of it wasn't. And I fantasized
about, well, maybe someday I can actually
have a shop, a real shop or something large where
I can be doing some kind of industrious activity,
and didn't know how. And money was always
relevant anyway, but you don't even know how
you're ever going to get it. The space seeds were
planted there, and then I was lucky enough to
embark on that adventure by itself, which was
a really interesting process before I actually
built my buildings. Because you're having to, I
was my own general contractor and design things
and the buildings. And also, I experimented with
buying interest, small interest into some other
companies, and realized I didn't want to get into
rocketry. A lot of people were getting into that,
but they weren't getting into habitats. And the
space thing was, and still is, a real passion.
We're going to have another interview where we'll go into that in much greater depth.
In a way, we're jumping ahead of ourselves. But
the next episode that's worth talking about would
be in the 1980s, when you began engaging in
your own private research on UFO experiencers,
contactees, and witnesses of UFO sightings. I had
the time to really take up a literature study.
So, in order to understand what people are talking
about, the cases, the who, the where, the when,
the how type of things. So, I read every
book I could get a hold of that was credible
on psi and UFOs. And I read a book a week for a
year, a book a week. And I'm working full time.
I assume at that point in your life, you're well-established in the real estate market.
Well, yeah, there was no COVID. So, I'm working
every day. In fact, we never did stop during
COVID anyway. We never did. So, the research
was really important to be able to understand,
and the reading was really important. And then
I did interviews. And I wanted to hear personal
testimony, you know, like you're doing. And I
wanted to hear that. And so, I interviewed about
235 people. Someone would say, shut off the
tape recorder. Nobody knows what I'm going to be
telling you. You know, and I have a yellow pad,
and I would take my notes. And if I didn't have
a tape recorder. And these were in-your-face
encounters by these people. So, these were
all different kinds of really in-your-face kinds of experiences that these people had.
And how did you find them?
Some of it was a snowball effect. I would talk
to somebody and then ask them if they knew of
anybody else. And then ask those people. So, it
kind of spread like that. I also realized that
there was a locus, a center of activity in Nevada
out by in little towns that we have outside of Las
Vegas called Caliente, Pioche, and Panaca. And
it's just off of the test site a little ways off
the S4 area. Those people, that was a goldmine
of stories. People in those towns. I remember
talking to an owner of a cafe and one of her
staff. And they had been sitting outside at night,
and they were watching this football stadium
size object, like really close to the ground,
maybe 1,000 or 1,500 feet off the ground, really close, drifting across Caliente.
And what made that so fascinating was a year
later, I'm interviewing a minister. I think it
was Baptist minister. And he and his wife had come
out of eating, and I think they were with another
couple. And they look up in the sky and they see
the exact same thing from a different location.
And that helped clarify something that the people
told me that they mistook for appendages on the
craft, but they weren't. They were some type
of planes that were escorting this huge, huge
structure. So that was really an interesting
investigation for me because I confirmed it a
whole year later from people that were credible.
I mean, who wouldn't believe a Baptist minister,
you know? So there were credible people, multiple witnesses, and I did a multiple
at the initial. So those kinds of stories were really interesting.
Now, you said planes. Do you mean airplanes?
There appeared to be some kind of jets that
were escorting. There wasn't much noise, though.
There wasn't any. I don't remember them saying
that there was a huge rumble of any kind,
a lot of noise. I don't remember anything
like that. This thing was gigantic in the sky,
and it was being escorted where the people thought
these lights were appendages on some kind of bars
or tubes coming out, very long, and with lights
on them for some reason. Well, it turned out from
the other perspective, they were aircraft is what
they were, you know? So lights from the aircraft.
Well, the implication being that the large
object was not human, but the aircraft were.
Maybe, yes or no. You don't know for sure. In that kind of context, you have so little
information. You don't know who's making the
big giant craft and who's making the planes or
whatever the escorts are, whether they're in fact
even they are planes. Maybe there's some other
kind of UFO that's made to mimic because you
can have UFOs in any shape you can think of,
any kind of shape you can imagine.
Well, at the same time, you're doing very well in
the real estate business. You've opened up a hotel
business, the budget suites, I presume.
So we're not a hotel. No. No, we've never been a motel. We've never been a hotel
because those income streams are not reliable
enough for me. I've owned, I built and operated
motels, maybe three or four. And I built a small
little hotel at one time, but the income streams
are not reliable enough. So I've been in the
apartment business and I accidentally picked
that up from my grandfather living next door
because he converted four horse stalls into
studio apartments. He had a little apartment
behind his garage and he had another separate
little house where when my mother was pregnant,
my dad was away in World War II. That's where we
stayed. And actually I was born and then that's
where we lived until he came home in 45. I was
born in 44. And so my grandfather was in the
apartment business. And I learned a couple
really important things. Three, you can rent small
places, but they better be clean. And it helps if
they're already furnished, right? And you better
be there to collect the rent. And if you have a
vacancy, it better look good and you better be
there to show it, right? So no screwing around. So
I learned that at a young age from watching him with his little, his apartments.
Now, I don't remember where I heard this. So you
could tell me if I'm wrong, but somewhere I heard
that you had the ambition to create an aerospace
company and you knew that you'd need a lot of
money to do that. And you went into the apartment
business with the idea of earning enough money to
create an aerospace company, which I guess is
what you did do. No, it was for survival reasons.
So I bounced around in college. I went up to UNR.
I went to Southern Nevada University. I went to
Orange Coast College. And then I found somebody
that would keep me. That was ASU. So I spent three
and a half years at Arizona State University. So
I'm a sun devil. And so during all that, I wound up
eventually getting married and we had a baby and
a little boy. And then she's pregnant again as I'm
graduating, she's pregnant again. And I have
a Chevy that's paid for and we had $1,000. And
mostly that was save money we save from wedding gifts that we got, you know,
pass the hat around or whatever. And so I got a broker's license and
I started working for a brokerage company and
didn't sell much. And so I thought, well, I'll
just go all in. And so I opened up my own office
and I had a couple of salesmen and I'm about 20,
23, 24 years old at that time. And I started
buying property. A fourplex in a house was my
first deal with no money down, really very little
money. And a couple of deals were nothing, you
know. But I had to put myself in the seller's
shoes because if I would take the deal, it's worth
presenting it. And I sincerely on my propositions
felt that if I were in the same shoes,
I would, by God, I would go ahead and take the deal. I would take the deal. So I began
accumulating a portfolio of these things for a financial statement.
And so mainly they all cash flowed, they had
positive net incomes. And so that's how I got
into the apartment business because I had a
family to feed and I wasn't making it as a real
estate salesman well enough. It was not dependable enough income.
But the apartment business obviously worked out well.
Well, I worked period of time. I got a general
contractor's license and I built 15,000
apartments for my own portfolio. And I began to
buy other people's apartments. I bought 8,000
units that belonged to banks that they had gotten in foreclosure. And maybe blocks of
3,000 at a time or 2,400 at a time, you know.
And I got interested in a couple of banks
kind of thing. So I probably in my subconscious
wanted to do something in science, right?
Not knowing exactly how, when, but it takes money,
right? Takes more than it takes to feed a family,
right? And I was financially responsible in not having a high style of living.
We lived off about 10% of the net after-tax
income. That's what we lived off of. So that
there was a large amount to do something with,
right? And so eventually that was the aerospace
and it's a big consumer.
Well, and I gather prior to building the aerospace company, you had
founded the National Institute of Discovery Science, NIDS. After you had done a year's
worth of very serious interviewing of contactees
and reading the available literature, that's when
you founded NIDS.
Yeah. Yeah. I managed to meet a lot of the great researchers.
John Mack, I supported him in some of his research and Bud Hopkins, Dave Jacobs,
a lot of the famous researchers and others. And they were really quality
people in the whole field of inquiry. And they have been around the block so much
and been involved in so many things. So I sponsored
everything, crop circles, cattle mutilations,
and oh boy, they can be really foul. And so
sat at a lot of aggressive hypnosis sessions,
writing out questions where you have somebody
that may have been an abductee, doing that kind
of thing. Of course, looking at a lot of
photographs, looking at doing forensics on materials
extracted from different places and so on. Usually, if anybody has anything,
when people say, well, did you come across
something? Well, the question is silly because
if you ever have anything that's really more than
just a piece of material, you're not going to say
anybody that I don't have anything, but you're
not going to say to anybody that you do because
it could be confiscated. It depends on the
pedigree of how you acquired it and who also
had it. And at one time, was it the federal
governments? So if it was one time the federal
governments all of a sudden you have it and now
you're the bullseye on trying to extract it from
you, right? And so in fact, that's why the
government has very little. It's corporations
that do and because a FOIA doesn't work with corporations. That's the main reason.
